columns.text: In this exercise, we will compute for the financial break-even quantity.

Isolate the term with the variable then divide both sides by $9,600$

$$\begin{aligned}
9,600P&=\$185,000+\$220,800\\[10pt]
9,600P&=\$405,800\\[10pt]
\dfrac{9,600P}{9,600}&=\dfrac{\$405,800}{9,600}\\[10pt]
P&=\$42.27
\end{aligned}$$

The price per unit is $\$42.27$

We can then substitute the known values to the formula to solve for $D$

$$\begin{aligned}
13,700&=\dfrac{\$185,000+D}{\$42.27-\$23}\\[15pt]
13,700&=\dfrac{\$185,000+D}{\$19.27}\\[15pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Multiply both sides by $\$19.27$ then isolate the variable

$$\begin{aligned}
13,700 \times \$19.27&=\$185,000+D\\[15pt]
\$263,999-\$185,000&=D\\[15pt]
\$78,999&=D
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation is valued at $\$78,999$

Since we already have the depreciation, we can solve for the initial investment by multiplying the depreciation to the number of years. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Initial investment}&= \text{D} \times \text{Time}\\
&=\$78,999 \times 5\\
&=\$394,995
\end{aligned}$$

Using an annuity factor table, we can see that in $5$ years and a required return of $12\%$, we have a factor of $3.605$.

Substitute this to get the OCF:

$$\begin{aligned}
\$394,995&=\text{OCF}\times 3.605\\[15pt]
\text{OCF}&=\dfrac{\$394,995}{3.605}\\[15pt]
&=\$109,568.65
\end{aligned}$$

Using the formula for the financial break-even point, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Q}&=\dfrac{\text{FC + OCF}}{\text{P - v}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\$185,000+\$109,568.65}{\$42.27-\$23}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\$294,568.65}{\$19.27}\\[15pt]
&=15,286.39
\end{aligned}$$

The financial break-even point is $15,286.39$ units.
